author: Nikola Paunović
title: Cardmintano - Native Token Minter
description: Ability to mint native tokens is already here for some time, but there's no user friendly way of doing it.

assessments.note: The proposal has addressed a current need that may drive some user adoption.

Not clear what simple GUI token generation ability actually provides. What is the use case? Without coding up something more complex (in which case you would not need this), why would someone mint a random token?

Whilst this is a challenge now, it can hardly be seen as a big one for the future. As the proposer himself admits, future Daedalus releases will deploy this very functionality in the official wallets (unsure of Yoroi but I assume there will be a light version too). Had this proposal been presented in Fund1 or Fund2, prior to Mary, its importance would have been higher and the need to address the challenge more immediate. Only a  middle rating was given this challenge because the date when wallet coin-minting functionality has not yet been confirmed and if it is in line with the release of Alonzo, then a 3/4 month wait is not that long. however, as it stands and if it can be delivered in the near future then there is a benefit...hence the middle rating.

The problem description and solution are reasonable. The proposal presented is within the scope of the challenge. Making the minting process for native assets more user friendly is an important step to increase adoption. A less technical minting model can increase the user base and this can generate a chain effect, as it is easier for mint assets, new projects will benefit.

The proposer is committed to developing relevant implementations.  Metrics were not included to measure the potential for impact.

In general, I see the proposal as promising, I recommend only a clearer definition of success through goals and metrics so that the potential for impact can be more evident.

The idea appears to be a valid use case of a Dapp that would add value for the community and as such addresses the challenge. The proposal has been initiated but needs further refinement which this funding would address.
The self-introduction is not enough to convey the skill required to implement most of the features nor does further investigation on GitHub.
Proposer has demo up and running. A more detailed plan and uses cases would be useful.

The proposer has presented a test (MAC only) version of the functionality which interacts with the testnet and that provides a level of confidence that there is a chance for success. However, the admittance that an official minting functionality will be built in the official wallets almost forces the proposal to list more novel priorities. This proposal would benefit from a listing of the dev pathways for each of the items including a matrix of resources x costing, which breaks down the claimed 200 hours of work required. The timing of the release should also be prominent including what-if scenarios if there is a delay in the official releases or this proposed solution. Fund 5 funds are disbursed on the 26th of June so there should be clear statements about how the timeline of this dev matches with the IOHK minting functionality. When is the 200 hours of work starting? And if it starts after receiving the funds, how does its release align with the official version?  There is a possibility that this solution could be redundant by the time it's released.

The proposer described experience in software engineering, as a co-founder of a tech company and as a participant in the Plutus Pioneer Program. The proposal is already under development and an initial version of the application can now be used. The development can be checked on Github and there are technical details on how to use it.

The requested budget is for the payment of the proposer and is estimated at 200 hours of work, which is within the expectation for what is expected of a software developer / engineer.

The redundancy risk of the proposal was considered and this is due to the fact that IOG is also working on a similar type of implementation.

The plan needs to be better structured. There is no timeline / roadmap.

The proposer has the relevant experience to successfully implement the proposal and appears to be well along the track of development. The plan is a little light on for detail but I feel this may be more to do with proposer characteristics. I certainly feel the proposal will be improved with further iterations and increased community collaboration.

The proposal only includes an upper limit on work hours and a wish list of things that the proposer hopes to implement within that allotted time. Information of what can be realistically be completed within the funded period is missing.
Its not clear how this simple functionality would be useful. Could the proposer give some example use cases that would drive widespread repeated usage?

The proposal presents enough information to provide confidence regarding its feasibility. The proposer has already built a test version which any user can play with. Where the score is reflected is how it will effectively address the challenge, if it is still a valid challenge at all at this point of Cardano development. Had this been presented in Funds 1-3, there iwould have been a greater need for its development. That said and should this proposal proceed, the use of GitHub and reddit provides a level of transparency that will allow audit of the project. But better listing of each step of the process, assuming the priorities will not change, is required in order for the community to check progress stage by stage.

The project will be open source, which is a favorable point for auditability.

A budget breakdown has been described (although there is no clear definition, it is possible to identify that the budget will be used to pay the proposer for 200 hours of work).

Relevant goals / deliverables have been defined.

The project is already under development and there is a link to Github where it is possible to confirm that the work already exists.

I recommend the inclusion of metrics / KPIs and a roadmap to make auditability clearer.

The information provided is adequate without being as explicit as I would like for a non-technical audience. Having said that the proposer is open to questions and has a valid use case in mind. The Reddit community certainly engaged with the concept and the proposer adequately fielded the enquiries and with this approach I am confident good work may come with this proposal.

solution: Create a cross-platform solution with an easy to use graphical interface that would allow less technical users to mint native tokens.
experience: I am an experienced software engineer, co-founder at a tech company and participant in the Plutus Pioneer Program.
